A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring Isomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field involves the group formed by all nonzero elements of a finite field $\mathbb{F}_q$, denoted as $\mathbb{F}_q^*$. This group is cyclic of order $q-1$. The definition focuses on the group structure (associativity, identity, inverses) of the nonzero elements under multiplication.

The concept of a Ring Isomorphism involves a bijective ring homomorphism between two rings, ensuring that the ring structure (addition and multiplication operations) is preserved and reversible between the two rings.

To define and understand the Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field, the focus is solely on the properties of the group under multiplication, specifically the existence of an identity element, the existence of inverses for each element, and the closure under multiplication. These properties are inherent to the nonzero elements of a finite field and do not require the concept of a ring isomorphism, which deals with the structure-preserving correspondence between two different rings.

Therefore, the concept of a Ring Isomorphism is not necessary for the definition or understanding of a Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field. The latter can be fully understood and defined using only the properties of groups and the specific characteristics of finite fields, without reference to isomorphisms between different ring structures.
